For each query (x, y): 
  The customer must purchase at least x items. To maximize the free value (which is the sum of the cheapest y items in the purchase), 
  the customer would want to have as many cheap items as possible in the purchase. However, note that the free items are the cheapest y in the purchase.
  The strategy: the customer will buy exactly x items. Why? Because if they buy more, they might include items that are more expensive and hence not free? 
  But note: the problem says "if a customer purchases at least x items, then the y cheapest are free". So we can choose any set of at least x items.
  However, to maximize the free value, we want the y cheapest to be as large as possible. How? 
  We can choose which items to buy. We want to have y free items that are as expensive as possible. But note: the free items are the cheapest among the purchased ones.
  Therefore, we want to have a set that has y items that are as expensive as possible, but note that if we include too many cheap items, then the free ones (the cheapest) will be the cheap ones.

  Alternate approach: 
  Since we are allowed to choose any set of at least x items, we can choose exactly x items (because if we choose more, we can always drop the extra ones and not harm the free part: because the free part is the y cheapest, and if we drop an item that is not among the y cheapest, then the free part remains the same; but if we drop an item that is among the y cheapest, then we might get a cheaper set of free items? Actually, we want the free items to be as expensive as possible. So including more items might allow us to have a set of y free items that are more expensive?

  Actually, the optimal strategy is to buy exactly x items. Why?
  Because if we buy more than x, say x+k, then the free items are the y cheapest in the entire set. But note that we can always choose a subset of exactly x items that contains the y items we want to be free and the rest being the most expensive ones. However, including extra items that are cheaper than the ones we have would force the free set to include those cheaper ones?
